name: SOX IT General Controls
description: Sarbanes-Oxley Act Section 404 — IT General Controls for financial reporting systems

domains.name: Access to Programs and Data
domains.description: Controls ensuring that access to IT systems and data supporting financial reporting is appropriately restricted to authorized individuals based on job responsibilities and business need

controls.title: User Access Provisioning
controls.description: New user access to financially significant applications and supporting infrastructure is formally requested, appropriately approved by management, and provisioned based on job responsibilities and the principle of least privilege before access is granted.

controls.title: User Access Modification
controls.description: Changes to existing user access rights (role changes, transfers, promotions) are formally requested, approved by appropriate management, and implemented in a timely manner to reflect current job responsibilities.

controls.title: User Access Deprovisioning / Termination
controls.description: Access to financially significant applications, operating systems, and databases is revoked in a timely manner upon employee termination, contractor end-of-engagement, or when access is no longer required for job responsibilities.

controls.title: Periodic User Access Reviews
controls.description: Management performs periodic reviews (at least quarterly for privileged access, semi-annually for standard access) of user access to financially significant applications to validate that access remains appropriate and commensurate with job responsibilities.

controls.title: Privileged Access Management
controls.description: Elevated or administrative access to operating systems, databases, and applications supporting financial reporting is restricted to authorized personnel, formally approved, and subject to enhanced monitoring and periodic review.

controls.title: Segregation of Duties — Application Level
controls.description: Segregation of duties (SoD) conflicts within financially significant applications are identified, documented, and either prevented through system configuration or mitigated through compensating controls and monitoring.

controls.title: Segregation of Duties — IT Functions
controls.description: Segregation of duties is maintained between IT functions (development, testing, operations, security administration) to prevent unauthorized changes to production systems and data supporting financial reporting.

controls.title: Authentication Controls
controls.description: Authentication mechanisms (password complexity, multi-factor authentication, session management) are implemented for financially significant applications and supporting infrastructure to verify user identity before granting access.

controls.title: Service Account and Shared Account Management
controls.description: Service accounts, system accounts, and shared accounts used by financially significant applications are inventoried, have designated owners, use strong credentials, and are subject to periodic review and monitoring.

controls.title: Database Access Controls
controls.description: Direct access to databases supporting financial reporting is restricted to authorized database administrators, all direct data modifications are logged and reviewed, and production data access is controlled independently of application-level access.

controls.title: Network Access Controls
controls.description: Network access to systems and environments supporting financial reporting is controlled through firewalls, network segmentation, VPN, and intrusion detection/prevention systems to restrict access to authorized traffic only.

controls.title: Remote Access Controls
controls.description: Remote access to systems and networks supporting financial reporting is secured through encrypted connections (VPN, SSH), multi-factor authentication, and monitored to detect unauthorized access attempts.

controls.title: Physical Access to IT Assets
controls.description: Physical access to data centers, server rooms, and network equipment supporting financial reporting systems is restricted to authorized personnel through physical security controls and monitored via access logs and surveillance.

controls.title: Access Logging and Monitoring
controls.description: Access events (successful and failed logins, privilege escalations, data access) for financially significant systems are logged, retained for an appropriate period, and monitored for anomalous or unauthorized activity.

controls.title: Access Control Policy and Standards
controls.description: A formal access control policy and supporting standards are documented, approved by management, communicated to relevant personnel, and reviewed at least annually to ensure alignment with regulatory requirements and business objectives.

domains.name: Program Changes / Change Management
domains.description: Controls ensuring that changes to IT systems and applications supporting financial reporting are authorized, tested, approved, and implemented in a controlled manner to maintain system integrity

controls.title: Change Management Policy and Procedures
controls.description: A formal change management policy and supporting procedures are documented, approved, and communicated, defining the process for requesting, evaluating, approving, testing, and implementing changes to systems supporting financial reporting.

controls.title: Change Request and Documentation
controls.description: All changes to financially significant applications and supporting infrastructure are formally documented through change requests that include the nature, justification, risk assessment, and impact analysis of the proposed change.

controls.title: Change Authorization and Approval
controls.description: Changes to systems supporting financial reporting are approved by appropriate management (business owner and IT management) prior to implementation, with emergency changes subject to retrospective approval within a defined timeframe.

controls.title: Change Testing and Validation
controls.description: Changes to financially significant applications are tested in a non-production environment prior to deployment, including functional testing, regression testing, and user acceptance testing (UAT) with documented results and sign-off.

controls.title: Separation of Development and Production Environments
controls.description: Development, testing, staging, and production environments for financially significant applications are logically or physically separated, with controls preventing unauthorized migration of code or configuration between environments.

controls.title: Production Deployment Controls
controls.description: Migration of changes to production is performed by authorized personnel (not developers) through a controlled deployment process with rollback procedures, deployment verification, and post-implementation review.

controls.title: Emergency Change Management
controls.description: Emergency changes to systems supporting financial reporting follow a defined expedited process with appropriate authorization, are documented retroactively within a defined timeframe, and are subject to post-implementation review.

controls.title: Configuration Management
controls.description: Baseline configurations for servers, databases, and network devices supporting financial reporting are documented, maintained in a configuration management system, and changes to configurations follow the standard change management process.

controls.title: Patch Management
controls.description: Security patches and updates for operating systems, databases, and applications supporting financial reporting are assessed, tested, approved, and applied in a timely manner based on criticality and risk, with patching status tracked and reported.

controls.title: Source Code Version Control
controls.description: Source code for financially significant applications is maintained in a version control system with access restricted to authorized developers, branching and merging strategies enforced, and a complete audit trail of all code changes.
typical_evidence: Code commit history and audit trail

controls.title: Code Review and Quality Assurance
controls.description: Changes to application source code are subject to peer code review or quality assurance review by an individual other than the developer prior to approval for deployment to production environments.

controls.title: Change Monitoring and Reporting
controls.description: Change activity for financially significant systems is monitored and reported to management, including metrics on change volume, emergency changes, failed changes, and unauthorized changes detected through integrity monitoring.

domains.name: Program Development
domains.description: Controls ensuring that new systems and applications supporting financial reporting are developed, acquired, and implemented in a controlled manner with appropriate authorization, testing, and validation

controls.title: System Development Lifecycle (SDLC) Methodology
controls.description: A formal system development lifecycle methodology is documented, approved, and followed for the development or acquisition of new applications and significant enhancements to existing applications supporting financial reporting.

controls.title: Requirements Definition and Approval
controls.description: Business and technical requirements for new systems or significant changes to existing systems are formally documented, reviewed with stakeholders, and approved by business owners and IT management prior to development or acquisition.

controls.title: Security Requirements in Development
controls.description: Security requirements including access controls, data protection, audit logging, and segregation of duties are defined and incorporated into the design of new applications supporting financial reporting from the outset.

controls.title: System Design and Architecture Review
controls.description: System design and architecture for financially significant applications is reviewed and approved by qualified personnel to ensure alignment with business requirements, security standards, and IT architecture standards before development proceeds.

controls.title: Development Testing — Unit and Integration
controls.description: Developers perform unit testing and integration testing during development with documented test cases, expected results, and actual results to verify that code functions as specified in the requirements.

controls.title: User Acceptance Testing (UAT)
controls.description: Business users perform formal user acceptance testing of new systems or significant changes with documented test scenarios based on business requirements, and provide written sign-off before production deployment is authorized.

controls.title: Data Conversion and Migration
controls.description: Data conversion and migration activities for new systems are planned, tested, validated through reconciliation, and approved by data owners to ensure completeness and accuracy of financial data transferred to the new system.

controls.title: Third-Party Software and Vendor Assessment
controls.description: Acquisition of third-party software or cloud services supporting financial reporting includes security assessment, vendor due diligence, contract review for SOX compliance requirements, and validation that controls meet organizational standards.

controls.title: Go-Live Authorization
controls.description: Deployment of new systems or major releases to production is formally authorized by management based on successful completion of all testing phases, resolution of critical defects, and readiness confirmation from business and IT stakeholders.

controls.title: Post-Implementation Review
controls.description: Post-implementation reviews are performed after new systems or significant changes are deployed to production, evaluating whether objectives were met, lessons learned are documented, and any residual issues are tracked to resolution.

domains.name: Computer Operations
domains.description: Controls ensuring that IT systems supporting financial reporting are operated reliably, data is processed completely and accurately, and issues are detected and resolved in a timely manner

controls.title: Batch Processing and Job Scheduling
controls.description: Batch jobs and scheduled processes that affect financial data are documented, scheduled through an automated job scheduling system, monitored for successful completion, and subject to controls preventing unauthorized modification of schedules.

controls.title: Batch Job Failure Management
controls.description: Failed batch jobs and processing exceptions that affect financial data are detected through automated alerting, investigated by operations personnel, resolved in a timely manner, and documented with root cause analysis when applicable.

controls.title: Data Backup Procedures
controls.description: Backups of data, configurations, and applications supporting financial reporting are performed according to a defined schedule, with backup completeness verified, and backup media stored securely in an offsite or geographically separate location.

controls.title: Backup Restoration Testing
controls.description: Restoration of backups for financially significant systems is tested periodically (at least annually) to validate that backup data can be successfully recovered within defined recovery time objectives (RTO) and recovery point objectives (RPO).

controls.title: Disaster Recovery Planning
controls.description: Disaster recovery plans are documented for IT systems supporting financial reporting, specifying recovery procedures, roles and responsibilities, communication protocols, and recovery priorities aligned with business continuity requirements.
typical_evidence: DR contact lists and escalation procedures

controls.title: Disaster Recovery Testing
controls.description: Disaster recovery plans for financially significant systems are tested at least annually through tabletop exercises, simulation tests, or full failover tests, with results documented and plans updated to address identified gaps.
typical_evidence: Updated DR plans based on test findings

controls.title: System and Infrastructure Monitoring
controls.description: IT systems and infrastructure supporting financial reporting are monitored for availability, performance, and capacity, with alerts configured for threshold breaches and operations personnel responsible for timely response to issues.

controls.title: Incident Management
controls.description: IT incidents affecting financially significant systems are detected, logged, categorized by severity, escalated according to defined procedures, resolved in a timely manner, and subject to root cause analysis for significant incidents.

controls.title: Problem Management
controls.description: Recurring incidents and systemic issues affecting financially significant systems are identified through trend analysis, formally tracked as problems, investigated for root cause, and resolved through permanent corrective actions.

controls.title: Data Center Environmental Controls
controls.description: Data centers housing systems supporting financial reporting are equipped with environmental controls including temperature regulation (HVAC), humidity monitoring, fire detection and suppression, water leak detection, and uninterruptible power supplies (UPS).

controls.title: Data Integrity and Processing Controls
controls.description: Automated controls (input validation, processing reconciliation, output verification) are implemented within financially significant applications to ensure completeness, accuracy, and validity of financial data processing.

controls.title: End-User Computing (EUC) Controls
controls.description: End-user computing tools (spreadsheets, databases, scripts) used in financial reporting processes are inventoried, risk-assessed, and subject to appropriate controls including access restrictions, version control, change management, and integrity validation.

controls.title: IT Governance and Risk Management
controls.description: An IT governance framework is established with defined roles and responsibilities, IT risk assessment processes, policies and standards, and regular reporting to management and the audit committee on IT risks and control effectiveness.
typical_evidence: IT policy inventory and review records
